a36_legal_basis_summary: EDREAMS claimed processing was based on contract execution under Article 6(1)(b) GDPR for flight bookings. The DPA did not challenge this legal basis but focused on the violation of Article 12 regarding charging for rectification rights.
a75_case_summary: EDREAMS charged a customer €50 for correcting a name error on a flight ticket, violating Article 12 GDPR which requires free exercise of data subject rights. The DPA found this was a manual error by an agent who failed to clarify the charge breakdown. EDREAMS took remedial actions including refunding the customer, compensating the full trip cost, and implementing staff training. The DPA issued a warning instead of a fine considering it a minor first-time infringement with prompt mitigation measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered multiple mitigating factors: the minor nature of the infringement, the negligent rather than intentional character, actions taken to mitigate damage including full refund and compensation, implementation of organizational measures through staff training, no previous infringements, and cooperation with the authority. These factors led to a warning instead of a financial penalty.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The defendant claimed legitimate interest for domestic protection purposes. The DPA found the camera positioning acceptable under data minimization principles but did not explicitly validate the legal basis.
a75_case_summary: Individual installed 4 exterior home surveillance cameras. DPA found camera positioning acceptable under data minimization principles but issued warning for lack of informational signage. Ordered placement of visible informational signs within 10 days.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed to have managed the right to object but continued sending marketing SMS through third-party agents. The DPA found violations of data deletion obligations and security measures.
a75_case_summary: The Spanish DPA sanctioned XFERA MÓVILES for continuing to send marketing SMS after the data subject exercised right to object, and for security failures allowing access to third-party data. The company paid a reduced fine of €90,000 acknowledging responsibility. Violations included Articles 17, 32, and 5(1)(f) GDPR, and Article 21 LSSI.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included duration of offense, negligence, manner of discovery, and continuing nature. The company received a 20% reduction for acknowledgment and 20% for voluntary payment.

a75_case_summary: A homeowners association installed CCTV cameras that excessively recorded public transit areas and sidewalks beyond their private perimeter. The Spanish DPA found this violated Article 5(1)(c) GDPR (data minimization principle) as the cameras captured unnecessary public areas without justification. The DPA imposed a €3,000 fine and ordered correction of camera orientation within one month.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature of the infringement (capturing public areas without cause) and negligence (poor camera orientation) as aggravating factors under Article 83(2)(a) and (b). No mitigating factors were discussed. The fine was set at the lower scale for this type of violation.

a75_case_summary: The Spanish DPA sanctioned PSC political party for violating purpose limitation principle under Article 5(1)(b) GDPR. A doctor provided patient data to the party which used it for political campaigning without consent. The party processed this data for electoral purposes incompatible with the original medical purpose.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the negligent character aggravating under Article 83(2)(b) and the basic personal identifiers affected as aggravating under Article 83(2)(g). Other factors were not systematically discussed.

a75_case_summary: Spanish telecom company Xfera Móviles breached Article 5(1)(f) integrity and confidentiality when a third party accessed complainant's personal data (name, surname, ID, phone number) through an invoice error. The DPA found failure to implement adequate security measures and proactive responsibility violations. A €70,000 fine was imposed along with an order to bring processing into compliance within 10 days.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors discussed: nature/gravity/duration (aggravating), negligent character (aggravating), categories of data affected (aggravating), and cooperation with authority (aggravating due to non-response). Other factors not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) but the DPA found it invalid because they failed to implement the 30-day data blocking requirement under Spanish law (LOPDGDD Article 20.1(c)), which made the processing unlawful.
a75_case_summary: Equifax processed claimant's credit data without blocking it for 30 days as required by Spanish law LOPDGDD Article 20.1(c). The DPA found this violated Article 6(1)(f) GDPR as the processing lacked lawful basis. A €75,000 fine was imposed considering the negligent nature and duration of the infringement.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered two aggravating factors: significant negligence (Art 83.2(b)) and duration of illegitimate processing (Art 83.2(d)). No mitigating factors were discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful based on contracts and recordings appearing legitimate, but the DPA found no valid legal basis as the data subject never consented to processing and the controller failed to verify the identity of those claiming to represent the data subject.
a75_case_summary: Orange España processed complainant's personal data for six telephone lines without valid legal basis. The DPA found the company failed to verify identity of those claiming to represent the data subject and lacked proper consent. The appellate court upheld the €80,000 fine for violation of Article 6(1) GDPR.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the negligent character of the infringement as aggravating, the nature of basic personal identifiers affected as aggravating, and did not discuss other Article 83(2) factors in detail.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed no disclosure occurred in an internal chat, but the DPA found public disclosure of customer personal data on Amazon without any legal basis that legitimizes the processing.
a75_case_summary: A Spanish retailer publicly disclosed customer personal data including names, addresses, and phone numbers on Amazon in response to negative reviews. The DPA found violations of Articles 6 and 5(1)(f) GDPR for unlawful processing and breach of confidentiality. The company was fined €4,000 and ordered to remove the data and implement compliance measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered intentionality, nature of the offense, privacy impact, public accessibility of data, and categories of data affected as aggravating factors. The SME status of the entity was considered mitigating. The fine was set at €4,000 based on these considerations.

a75_case_summary: Private individual installed CCTV camera oriented toward public space and school area without information poster, ignoring police warnings. DPA found violation of Article 5(1)(c) GDPR due to excessive data collection. Fine imposed for intentional persistence of conduct and impact on community.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity (Art 83(2)(a)) aggravating due to discomfort caused, intentional character (Art 83(2)(b)) aggravating due to persistence after warnings, and previous infringements (Art 83(2)(e)) aggravating due to recurrence.

a75_case_summary: The Spanish DPA sanctioned KUKIMBIA S.L. for abandoning documentation containing personal data of customers and suppliers in a public area. The company failed to implement adequate security measures under Article 32.1 GDPR, allowing unauthorized access to personal data. The DPA found the conduct deeply negligent and imposed a €3,000 fine considering the local scope but aggravating factors including lack of cooperation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature/gravity/duration as aggravating due to abandoned documentation affecting many people. Intentional/negligent character was aggravating as conduct was deeply negligent. Actions to mitigate damage were aggravating as no measures were adopted. Technical measures were aggravating due to security breach. Cooperation was aggravating as no response to information request. Other factors were mitigating as it was a small business.

a75_case_summary: Spanish DPA investigated HAPPY FRIDAY, SL following a complaint about cookie practices and security measures. While security measures were found compliant, the cookie policy violated LSSI Article 22.2 by lacking clear information and granular consent mechanisms. The company paid a reduced fine of €1500 after acknowledging responsibility and making voluntary payment.

Vodafone España was sanctioned for violating Article 48.1.b of Spanish Telecommunications Law in relation to Article 21 GDPR by making persistent marketing calls to a claimant who had exercised his right to object in 2017. The AEPD found Vodafone responsible as controller for calls made by its processors using both Vodafone-provided databases and their own databases. The sanction was based on Vodafone's failure to honor the data subject's objection right and its history of over 50 previous similar violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The AEPD considered aggravating factors including previous offenses, benefit obtained by the offender, damage caused, and lack of cessation of infringing activity. Mitigating factors included remedial actions taken. The sanction amount was set at €50,000 representing 2.5% of the maximum possible fine.

a75_case_summary: DE VERE SPAIN SL made commercial call to claimant despite claimant having previously exercised right to erasure and being informed no personal data was held. The Spanish DPA found violation of Article 48.1.b) LGT in relation to Article 21 GDPR regarding right to object to marketing calls. Defendant paid reduced fine of €4000 through voluntary payment procedure.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors were briefly discussed: nature/gravity/duration was aggravating; intentional/negligent character was aggravating; categories of personal data affected was aggravating. Other factors were not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent and contract as legal bases; DPA found these valid but noted legal obligation basis was not applicable as it requires formal law; no explicit invalidation of claimed bases
a75_case_summary: MyHeritage faced complaint regarding GDPR violations including inadequate information provision and cookie usage. Spanish DPA found breaches of Article 13 GDPR (transparency/information obligations) and LSSI Article 22.2 regarding cookies. The company paid a reduced fine of €16,000 to terminate the procedure without admitting responsibility.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed contract execution under Article 6(1)(b) but DPA found invalid as the sister lacked proper representation authority; DPA held processing unlawful without valid legal basis.
a75_case_summary: Electricity provider modified contract terms without valid authorization; sister called claiming to live at address but lacked proper representation authority; DPA found inadequate security protocol and invalid legal basis under Article 6(1)(b); imposed fines for Articles 6 and 32 violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered negligence aggravating under Article 83(2)(b); linked activity with personal data processing as aggravating; security measures deficiency as aggravating; no mitigating factors discussed.

a75_case_summary: Individual hotel operator installed CCTV cameras capturing public space without justification. DPA found violation of data minimization principle (Article 5(1)(c)) and transparency obligations (Article 12). Fine imposed due to disproportionate surveillance affecting third parties and lack of mandatory information posters. Defendant ordered to install proper signage and provide information forms.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity of infringement as aggravating (affecting third parties), intentional/negligent character as aggravating (lacking mandatory posters), and previous infringements as mitigating (no prior violations). Other factors not discussed.

a7_defendant_name: SACRAMENTAL AND PENITENTIAL BROTHERHOOD OF OUR FATHER JESUS SACRAMENT AND MOST BLESSED MARY OF PIEDAD, AMPARO DE LOS LEONESES
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found confusing information regarding legal bases for email communications, mixing consent, contractual obligation, legitimate assignment and public sources without proper differentiation between statutory relationship maintenance and voluntary information purposes.
a75_case_summary: A religious brotherhood violated GDPR by sending emails without blind copy, exposing members' email addresses, and providing inadequate information about legal bases for email communications. The DPA found breaches of Articles 5.1.f), 13, and 32.1, ordering corrective measures but imposing only a warning sanction due to the entity's small size, non-profit nature, and lack of recidivism.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the entity's small size, non-profit nature, and lack of recidivism as mitigating factors, but did not systematically discuss Article 83(2) factors.

a75_case_summary: A Spanish consulting firm sent a client's personal data to another client via email. The Spanish DPA found violations of GDPR Article 5(1)(f) (integrity/confidentiality) and Article 32(1) (security measures). Fines were imposed totaling €3,000 for these breaches.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered aggravating factors: nature/gravity/duration, negligence, lack of mitigation measures, poor security measures, and lack of cooperation. Mitigating factors included the small business status and local scope of processing.

a75_case_summary: Spanish DPA initiated proceedings against Ramona Films SL for GDPR violations on adult website putalocura.com. The website had outdated privacy policy referencing repealed LOPD law instead of GDPR requirements, and cookie implementation issues including pre-consent cookie installation and inadequate consent mechanisms. The company paid a reduced fine of €8,000 through voluntary payment procedure without admitting responsibility.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered duration of infringement as aggravating (GDPR has been mandatory since May 2018), intentionality as aggravating, and categories of personal data (children's data) as aggravating. Other Article 83(2) factors were not discussed in the termination resolution.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller processed personal data without any legal basis. The DPA found violation of Article 6 GDPR as SMS were sent to claimant's mobile phone regarding billing despite previous requests for data deletion and assurances from Vodafone that the issue was resolved.
a75_case_summary: Vodafone España processed a former customer's personal data by sending SMS about invoice generation without legal basis, despite multiple complaints and assurances that the issue was resolved. The Spanish DPA found violation of Article 6 GDPR for unlawful processing. Vodafone acknowledged responsibility and paid a reduced fine of €60,000 using both available reductions.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, intentionality/negligence as aggravating, previous infringements as aggravating, cooperation as mitigating, and categories of data affected as aggravating. Other factors were not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller published personal data without necessary legitimation under Article 6.1 GDPR, specifically publishing a photograph and personal data of the claimant without express consent or other valid legal basis.
a75_case_summary: The Spanish DPA sanctioned a real estate company for GDPR violations. The website lacked proper privacy policy referencing outdated legislation and published personal data without consent. The DPA issued a warning for Article 13 violation and €8,000 fine for Article 6.1 violation. Aggravating factors included negligent action and complaint-based discovery.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) was partially discussed. The DPA considered the intentional/negligent character (b) as aggravating and the manner of discovery (h) as aggravating. Other factors were not discussed in the decision.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) GDPR for publishing a judicial sentence containing personal data on their website and Facebook. The DPA found this invalid as the legitimate interest did not prevail over the data subject's fundamental rights and freedoms, and the publication was not proportionate.
a75_case_summary: A sports club published a judicial sentence containing personal data of a former board member on its website and Facebook. The DPA found the publication violated Article 6(1) GDPR as the legitimate interest basis was invalid - the club's interest in informing members did not prevail over the data subject's rights. The publication was disproportionate and not limited to club members.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature, gravity and duration of the infringement as aggravating, noting the data remained accessible through search engines despite removal attempts. Intentionality/negligence was aggravating due to lack of diligence in data removal. Measures to mitigate damage were aggravating as adequate measures were not implemented.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found the controller violated data minimization principles by requiring excessive identification documents beyond what was necessary for the stated purposes of vacation rental service and compliance with Catalan police registration requirements.
a75_case_summary: The Spanish DPA sanctioned a UAE-based vacation rental company for GDPR violations. The company required excessive personal data including ID images beyond what was necessary for rental services and Catalan police registration requirements. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(c) (data minimization) and 13 (transparency obligations), imposing fines totaling €75,000.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature of processing personal data as essential to the defendant's business activity as aggravating, and found intentionality/negligence in the infringement as the defendant was fully aware of its procedures. No mitigating factors were discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found Vodafone processed claimant's personal data without legitimacy as they lacked documentation proving contracting of prepaid lines, violating Article 6.1 GDPR.
a75_case_summary: Vodafone Spain processed claimant's personal data for two prepaid phone lines without proper documentation or legitimacy. The DPA found violation of Article 6.1 GDPR due to lack of lawful basis for processing. Vodafone paid a reduced fine of €56,000 through voluntary payment mechanism.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered intentionality/negligence (Art 83.2.b) and link between business activity and data processing (Art 83.2.k) as aggravating factors. Other factors were not discussed in detail.

a75_case_summary: AVILON CENTER 2016 S.L. made marketing calls to a data subject whose phone number was registered on the Robinson advertising exclusion list. The company claimed a software error momentarily blocked access to the Robinson list during the call. The Spanish DPA found a violation of the right to object under Article 21 GDPR and Article 48.1.b) of Spain's Telecommunications Law. The company paid a reduced fine of €12,000 through voluntary payment and recognition of responsibility.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed no legal basis; DPA found no legitimate basis under Article 6.1 GDPR; processing was done without consent or authorization.
a75_case_summary: Individual published audiovisual material from court proceedings on Twitter without consent; DPA found violation of Article 6.1 GDPR as no legal basis existed; Fine imposed considering aggravating factors including scope of dissemination and negligent action.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors; Aggravating: nature/gravity/duration, intentional/negligent character, technical measures; Mitigating: offender not linked to data processing activities; Other factors not discussed.

a75_case_summary: Spanish police officer photographed complainant's ID with personal mobile phone during identification procedure at demonstration. DPA found violation of Article 32.1 GDPR due to lack of appropriate security measures. DPA issued warning sanction as defendant is public administration body.
NOT_DISCUSSED

a7_defendant_name: MINISTRY OF HEALTH OF THE COMMUNITY OF MADRID
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found the controller violated confidentiality principles despite having security measures like access logging and audits, as these were reactive rather than preventive measures that could have stopped unauthorized access to medical records.
a75_case_summary: The Madrid Ministry of Health was sanctioned for a nurse's unauthorized access to a colleague's medical records. The DPA found insufficient security measures despite existing protocols, as they were reactive rather than preventive. The controller failed to implement adequate access controls that would restrict healthcare professionals to only patients under their care.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature of health data and inadequate security measures as aggravating factors. No mitigating factors were discussed. The decision focused on the seriousness of the breach rather than systematic Article 83(2) analysis.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed no legal basis; DPA found violation of Article 6(1) due to lack of consent mechanism; No valid consent obtained as users could send data without affirmative action
a75_case_summary: Individual website owner operated e-commerce site without proper consent mechanism, privacy policy, or cookie compliance; DPA found violations of GDPR Article 6(1) (consent), Article 13 (transparency), and LSSI Article 22.2 (cookies); Defendant paid reduced fine of €1,800 acknowledging responsibility.

GEOPOST delivery driver improperly posted notice with complainant's personal data on outside of mailbox, exposing name, surname, address and phone number to third parties. DPA found violations of Article 5(1)(f) confidentiality principle and Article 32 security measures. Company argued human error but DPA held controller responsible for employee actions and inadequate security measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity/duration, negligent character, technical/organizational measures, categories of data affected. Mitigating: actions to mitigate damage, merger by absorption circumstance. Neutral: cooperation with authority.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) GDPR to justify sharing individualized heating consumption data with all community members. The DPA found this legal basis invalid as the data sharing constituted a breach of confidentiality principles.
a75_case_summary: A housing community shared individualized heating consumption data (by floor/letter) with all owners via email before a meeting. The Spanish DPA found this violated Article 5(1)(f) GDPR (integrity and confidentiality) as personal data was unduly exposed. The controller claimed legitimate interest but this was rejected. A €600 fine was proposed but reduced to €480 through voluntary payment.

a7_defendant_name: AXA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT MANAGERS IBERICA S.A.
a75_case_summary: AXA Real Estate sent encrypted USB with personal data via courier but included password in same envelope. USB was lost during transport. Spanish DPA found violation of Article 32 GDPR security obligations. Fine reduced from €100,000 to €80,000 due to voluntary payment.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating; intentional/negligent character was aggravating; measures to mitigate damage were mitigating; technical measures were aggravating; previous infringements were mitigating; cooperation was mitigating; categories of data were aggravating; manner infringement became known was mitigating.

a7_defendant_name: MINISTRY OF INCLUSION,SOCIAL SECURITY AND MIGRATION. SUBDIRECCIÓN GENERAL DE RECURSOS HUMANOS E INSPECCIÓN GENERAL DE SERVICIOS
a75_case_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

Hertz Spain erroneously associated complainant's email with another customer's rental contract, sending traffic fine notifications containing personal data to wrong recipient. Despite complainant's notification, second email was sent weeks later due to internal coordination failures. AEPD found violations of Articles 5(1)(f) and 32 GDPR but considered it minor, issuing warning instead of fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: AEPD discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity/duration was mitigating (isolated incident), measures to mitigate damage were mitigating (quick response), technical measures were aggravating (inadequate security). Other factors were not discussed. Overall assessment led to warning rather than fine.

a75_case_summary: The Spanish DPA sanctioned INFINITY ECOM S.L. for GDPR Article 13 violations regarding inadequate privacy policy information and LSSI Article 22.2 violations regarding improper cookie usage. The website lacked proper identification of the data controller, information about data subject rights, and compliant cookie consent mechanisms. The DPA imposed two €5,000 fines and ordered corrective measures within one month.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature and gravity of the infringement as aggravating, particularly the defendant's activity involving personal data processing. Intentionality was also considered aggravating. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent was requested but DPA found processing lacked legal basis under Article 6(1) GDPR as inclusion in WhatsApp groups without proper legitimization violated the principle of legality.
a75_case_summary: A former employee filed a complaint against VUKMAL TRADE for requiring use of personal mobile phones for work and including employees in WhatsApp groups without proper legal basis. The Spanish DPA found violation of Article 6(1) GDPR as processing lacked legitimization. The company paid a reduced fine of €1,200 and was ordered to bring processing into compliance within 6 months.

a36_legal_basis_summary: DIGI claimed processing was lawful under Article 6(1)(b) GDPR as necessary for contract execution. The AEPD found this legal basis invalid in this specific case because a third party impersonated the data subject and obtained a SIM duplicate, violating the principle of legality.
a75_case_summary: DIGI issued a duplicate SIM card to an impersonator who fraudulently obtained it from a distributor point of sale. The AEPD found DIGI violated Article 6(1) GDPR as the processing lacked a lawful basis when the duplicate was issued to a third party instead of the legitimate data subject. The AEPD rejected DIGI's arguments about prior phishing and imposed a €70,000 fine, citing inadequate diligence in identity verification procedures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The AEPD systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included the nature/gravity/duration of infringement, negligent character, degree of responsibility, and link between business activity and data processing. Mitigating factor was actions taken to mitigate damage. The absence of previous infringements and lack of benefits obtained were considered neutral factors, not mitigating.

a75_case_summary: The Spanish DPA and Spanish Association of Pediatrics launched a campaign promoting digital health of minors through parental awareness to reduce risks from intensive digital screen use; no GDPR violations or enforcement actions were discussed in the provided text; the text describes an educational initiative rather than a regulatory decision; no legal proceedings or findings were mentioned.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found the defendant violated confidentiality principles despite claimed security measures, as they failed to implement adequate access controls preventing unauthorized access to medical records.
a75_case_summary: The Madrid Health Department was sanctioned for unauthorized access to a hospital employee's medical records by a coworker. The DPA found insufficient security measures despite claimed protocols, violating confidentiality principles. The defendant failed to implement proper access controls limiting staff to patients under their care. Security measures were reactive rather than preventive.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including nature/gravity as aggravating, data categories as aggravating, and mitigation efforts as mitigating. The lack of adequate technical measures was considered aggravating while cooperation was neutral.

a75_case_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

Claimant exercised right to deletion against Google regarding a URL appearing in search results. Google initially refused but later re-examined and found the personal data was no longer published on the disputed website. The Spanish DPA verified the URL no longer appeared in search results and dismissed the claim as the complainant's rights were satisfied.

Vodafone España failed to respond to a data subject's right to object request regarding marketing emails sent after contract termination. The Spanish DPA found Vodafone violated Article 21 GDPR by not processing the objection request. The DPA ordered Vodafone to comply with the right to object within 10 days.

The Spanish DPA resolved a complaint against GOKOAN EDUCATION for failure to properly respond to a data subject's right to erasure request. The company required a photocopy of ID card for full deletion but had not requested identification during registration. The DPA found this requirement unjustified as the company showed no reasonable doubt about the claimant's identity. The resolution orders the company to comply with the erasure request within 10 business days.

a7_defendant_name: CONSEJERIA DESANIDAD DE LA COMUNIDAD DE MADRID - SERVICIO MADRILEÑO DE SALUD
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for public health purposes under Article 9(2)(h) and legal obligations under Spanish healthcare laws. The DPA found the processing valid based on Article 17(3)(b) and (c) exceptions to the right to erasure, as medical data was necessary for adequate healthcare provision.
a75_case_summary: The Spanish DPA dismissed a complaint against Madrid's public health service regarding right to erasure of medical records. The complainant requested deletion of four medical annotations but received partial compliance - three were deleted while one was retained as necessary for adequate healthcare. The DPA found the controller properly responded under Article 17 GDPR exceptions for public health and legal obligations. Medical treatment disagreements were deemed outside data protection scope.

a7_defendant_name: AMAZON WEB SERVICES EMEA SARL SUCURSAL EN ESPAÑA
a75_case_summary: Claimant exercised right to erasure regarding false criminal association information published on extraconfidencial.com. AWS claimed processor status and inability to unilaterally delete data. AEPD found AWS failed to properly respond to erasure request or document communication to controller. Ordered AWS to provide certification of compliance or justified denial within 10 days.

The Spanish DPA upheld a complaint against CaixaBank for failing to properly respond to a data subject's access request under Article 15 GDPR. The bank had provided incomplete information that the complainant alleged was fabricated and lacked supporting documentation. The DPA ordered CaixaBank to either fully comply with the access request or provide justified reasons for refusal within ten working days.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found that legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) prevailed for URLs containing professional information, as the public interest in accessing information about the claimant's professional activities outweighed data protection rights.
a75_case_summary: Claimant requested deletion of nine URLs from Google search results containing personal data. The AEPD found that URLs with professional information about the claimant's public activities were legitimately processed under Article 6(1)(f) legitimate interests, as public interest in accessing professional information outweighed data protection rights. The claim was dismissed.

The Spanish DPA upheld a complaint against BABY PALACE, S.L. for failure to respond to a data subject's access request under Article 15 GDPR. The company only provided an acknowledgment of receipt but no substantive response within the regulatory timeframe. The DPA ordered the company to comply with the access request within 10 working days and communicate its actions to the Agency.

Claimant filed right to erasure request against Google Inc. and Constitutional Court regarding search results linking his name to Constitutional Court rulings. AEPD found Google Inc. responsible as data controller under CJEU ruling and ordered removal of one URL from search results. Claim against Constitutional Court dismissed due to jurisdictional limitations.

Spanish DPA upheld complaint against EVO BANCO for failing to respond to data subject's access and deletion rights requests. The bank did not provide the legally required response within the established timeframe. The DPA ordered the bank to comply with the data subject's rights within ten working days and communicate actions taken to the Agency.

a7_defendant_name: ASSOCIACIÓ PER LA POLITICAL PARTICIPATION TO CATALUNYA
a75_case_summary: The Spanish DPA resolved a complaint regarding failure to respond to a right to erasure request. The defendant political association failed to respond to the complainant's erasure request within the legal timeframe. The DPA ordered the defendant to either comply with the erasure request or provide a reasoned denial within ten business days.

a7_defendant_name: ASSOCIACIÓ PER LA PARTICIPACIÓ POLITICA A CATALUNYA
a75_case_summary: The Spanish DPA ruled on a complaint regarding failure to respond to a data subject's right to erasure request. The defendant political association failed to respond to the complainant's deletion request and did not reply to the DPA during proceedings. The DPA found the defendant violated transparency obligations and the right to erasure by not providing any response. The resolution orders the defendant to either comply with the deletion request or provide a reasoned denial within ten business days.

The Spanish DPA upheld a complaint against Kutxabank for failing to properly respond to a data subject's access request regarding an alleged debt that led to account blocking. The bank provided incomplete information, failing to disclose banking products held or current debt status. The DPA ordered Kutxabank to provide complete access within 10 days, finding the access granted was insufficient under Article 15 GDPR.

Complaint regarding failure to properly address right to erasure request under Article 17 GDPR. Claimant requested removal of a Google My Business review URL. Google initially refused but later removed the content during proceedings due to policy violation. The AEPD found the claim formally justified but noted the right had been restored through the removal.

The Spanish DPA ruled on a data subject's right to erasure request regarding police records in the "persons" file. The police had denied cancellation citing Articles 22 and 23 of Organic Law 15/1999, referencing a conviction for sexual assault. The DPA found the response lacked proper motivation and ordered the police to provide a properly reasoned response within 10 days, either granting cancellation or explaining why it cannot proceed.

The Spanish DPA dismissed a parent's complaint against a school for alleged failure to respond to data access requests. The DPA found the parent requested documents through educational record access channels rather than GDPR Article 15 procedures. The school had provided responses through sectoral educational regulations, not denying access but directing to proper procedures.

The AEPD resolved a complaint against SERGAS for failure to respond to a data subject's access request regarding medical records. The DPA found SERGAS failed to document providing the medical history despite claiming to have addressed the right. The resolution orders SERGAS to either provide certification of compliance or reasoned denial within 10 business days.

The Spanish DPA upheld a complaint against Amazon Spain for failing to respond timely to an employee's data access request. The employee sought operational instructions and digital assistant communications for a disability claim. Amazon eventually responded but claimed certain data was automatically deleted after 7 days. The DPA found the response was extemporaneous but no additional actions were required.

a7_defendant_name: HEALTH SERVICE OF THE PRINCIPALITY OF ASTURIAS
a75_case_summary: The Spanish DPA resolved a complaint regarding failure to properly respond to a data subject's access request for medical records of her deceased mother. The Health Service of Asturias initially failed to respond but eventually provided the requested information during the procedure. The DPA found the claim formally upheld but no further action was needed as the rights had been restored through the belated response.

Complaint dismissed against CGT trade union for alleged failure to respond to right to erasure request. Agency found data had been deleted from union website and search results no longer returned complainant's name. Since claims were satisfied, procedure was dismissed as having no purpose.

Claimant exercised right of access regarding recruitment process data through InfoJobs platform; Defendant claimed it didn't store assessment data and client companies couldn't extract candidate information; AEPD found the access response incomplete as it failed to inform about data communications; Ordered defendant to provide complete access response within 10 days.

a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the implementation of the Court of Justice of the European Union Judgment on Google Spain and Inc v. AEPD and Mario Costeja C-131/12
a75_case_summary: Claimant requested Google to de-index URLs containing personal data related to criminal allegations. Google denied the request citing freedom of expression protections for news of public interest. AEPD found the information was current criminal news with public relevance and dismissed the claim, noting data protection rights do not override freedom of expression for matters of public interest.

Spanish DPA appellate decision regarding right of access claim against financial institution. The DPA initially dismissed the claim but on appeal reversed and ordered the company to provide the requested access to personal data including bank movements. The DPA found that contractual documents containing personal data fall under GDPR access rights.

The Spanish DPA resolved a complaint against SAGE SPAIN, SL for failure to respond to a data subject's access request under Article 15 GDPR. The controller initially failed to respond but eventually provided access during the procedure. The DPA considered the claim formally upheld since the response was issued extemporaneously, but no additional corrective measures were imposed as the data subject's rights were restored.

Spanish DPA ruled on complaint against Police Directorate General for failure to properly respond to data subject's access requests. Complainant sought access to photographs and fingerprints stored in police files but received incomplete responses or no response to seven successive requests. The DPA found the Police failed to fulfill access obligations under Article 15 GDPR and ordered them to provide complete access or a motivated denial within ten days.

a7_defendant_name: CONSEJERÍA DE SANIDAD DE LA COMUNIDAD DE MADRID - SERVICIO MADRILEÑO DE SALUD
a75_case_summary: The Spanish DPA ruled on a complaint regarding failure to comply with right of access to medical records. The defendant refused to send documentation abroad by mail despite proper identification. The DPA found the defendant could have used secure electronic means and ordered compliance with the access request within 10 days.

The Catalan DPA issued an opinion on whether a public transport entity can provide security guards' identification data (name, surname, TIP) to users who file complaints without obtaining the guards' consent. The opinion analyzes legal bases under Article 6 GDPR for sharing employee data with third parties. The decision provides guidance on lawful processing but does not constitute an enforcement action.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent but the DPA found it invalid because consent was not freely given; the club required consent for image processing as a condition for registration of minors in sports activities, which vitiated consent from the beginning.
a75_case_summary: A sports club required parents to consent to image processing of their minor children as a condition for registration in sports activities. The Spanish DPA found this violated Article 7 GDPR as consent was not freely given. The club acknowledged responsibility and paid a reduced fine of €600. The DPA also ordered corrective measures to respect data protection rights of those refusing consent.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature and gravity of the infringement as aggravating, the impact on minors' rights as aggravating, and the recognition of responsibility and voluntary payment as mitigating. Most Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a75_case_summary: The APDCAT issued a report on a claim regarding denial of access to a school bullying protocol application file. The Authority found that data protection regulations would not prevent the claimant from accessing information relating to his minor daughter under parental authority. The report analyzed access rights under both GDPR Article 15 and Spanish transparency laws, concluding that identifying data of public employees and third parties could be disclosed with appropriate redactions.

a2_authority_name: Autoritat Catalana de Protecció de Dades
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed public task legal basis under Article 6(1)(e). The DPA found this basis valid for video surveillance but invalid for biometric processing due to lack of specific legal authorization. The DPA concluded biometric processing lacked proper legal basis.
a75_case_summary: Barcelona City Council implemented facial recognition in public CCTV without proper legal basis. The DPA found biometric processing violated GDPR principles and lacked specific legal authorization. The system processed special category data without adequate safeguards. The DPA imposed corrective measures and a €240,000 fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically applied Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity of infringement, negligent character, inadequate technical measures, and special category data. Mitigating factors included cooperation with authority and actions to mitigate damage. Other mitigating factors were considered.
authority_name_raw: Autoritat Catalana de Protecció de Dades
authority_name_norm: Autoritat Catalana de Protecció de Dades

a75_case_summary: APDCAT issued report on access request to environmental pollution records from 1975-present. Found access to sanctioning files involving natural persons should be restricted under data protection laws, except for published sanctions of very serious offenses. Recommended anonymization of third-party data and allowing access to non-sanctioning environmental information.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed public interest mission under Article 6(1)(e) as legal basis. The DPA found this basis valid for communicating institutional information to citizens.
a75_case_summary: Tiana City Council created WhatsApp group for municipal communications without proper data protection measures. Failed to provide complete Article 13 information initially and failed to implement confidentiality safeguards allowing members to access each other's personal data. DPA found violations of Articles 13 and 25.1 GDPR.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed Article 6(1)(c) legal obligation basis; the DPA found this invalid as no specific legal authorization exists for biometric time control; no collective agreement or regulatory framework legitimizes this processing.
a75_case_summary: The City Council of La Canonja implemented a fingerprint-based time control system for municipal workers without proper legal basis or impact assessment. The DPA found processing of biometric data without Article 9 exception violated Article 5(1)(a) lawfulness principle. The failure to conduct a required data protection impact assessment violated Article 35. The Council was ordered to implement a non-biometric alternative system.
NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis but the DPA found no valid exception under Article 9.2 GDPR for processing special category biometric data.
a75_case_summary: A Catalan high school used facial recognition and fingerprint systems to monitor student attendance since 2011-2012. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 9, 13, and 28 GDPR for unlawful processing of special category biometric data, inadequate information provision, and lack of proper processor contract. The school dismantled the system voluntarily.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered lack of intentionality as mitigating, actions to dismantle the system as mitigating, and processing of special category data as aggravating. Other factors were not discussed.

a7_defendant_name: Department of Health of the Generalitat de Catalunya
a75_case_summary: The Department of Health of Catalonia operated a COVID-19 vaccination appointment website with security vulnerabilities that allowed unauthorized access to personal data including health information. The DPA found violations of Article 32 GDPR for inadequate security measures and failure to conduct proper risk analysis. A reprimand was issued along with an order to conduct a risk analysis within one month.

Eulen sent six emails to families/guardians of disabled care center users without using BCC, exposing email addresses and sometimes names/institutional affiliations. The DPA found violation of Article 5(1)(f) confidentiality principle due to lack of diligence by staff. The entity acknowledged responsibility and implemented measures to prevent recurrence.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included number of affected people and link between offender's activity and data processing. Mitigating factors included lack of intentionality, implemented security measures, non-special category data, and no profits obtained from infringement.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The legal basis discussion focused on Article 5(1)(f) integrity and confidentiality principle violation, not on Article 6 legal bases for processing.
a75_case_summary: Badalona City Council published personal data of 1,076 employees including names, positions, and salaries on its website due to human error. The document remained accessible for approximately 73 hours with 16 recorded accesses. The Catalan DPA found a violation of Article 5(1)(f) GDPR regarding integrity and confidentiality but did not impose a fine.

a2_authority_name: Council for Transparency and Protection of Data of Andalusia
a7_defendant_name: City Council of Jerez de la Frontera
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed public task basis but the DPA found the processing lacked legitimacy under Article 6 GDPR because the City Council failed to verify the marital property regime through available civil registry information before communicating debt data and initiating garnishment proceedings against the claimant.
a75_case_summary: The City Council of Jerez de la Frontera was sanctioned for violating Article 6 GDPR by processing personal data without legal basis. The City Council initiated debt collection proceedings against a claimant based on his wife's debt, assuming community property regime without verifying the actual separation of property regime through available civil registry information. The DPA found the City Council failed to conduct basic data verification procedures before communicating debt information and requesting data from other administrations.
authority_name_raw: Council for Transparency and Protection of Data of Andalusia
authority_name_norm: Council for Transparency and Protection of Data of Andalusia

a2_authority_name: Transparency and Data Protection Council of Andalusia
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for public task under Article 6(1)(e), but the DPA found no legal basis covered the audio recording of department meetings as it was not obligatory under Spanish public sector law.
a75_case_summary: An educational center recorded department meetings without proper legal basis under Article 6 GDPR. The DPA found violations of Articles 6 (lawfulness) and 13 (information obligations) as recordings were not legally required and teachers were not fully informed about processing details including retention periods.
authority_name_raw: Transparency and Data Protection Council of Andalusia
authority_name_norm: Transparency and Data Protection Council of Andalusia

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found legal basis under Article 6(1)(c) for compliance with legal obligations and Article 6(1)(e) for performance of public tasks, citing Spanish local government laws that grant councilors right to access information necessary for their functions.
a75_case_summary: Opinion regarding legality of including personal data in daily police incident reports sent to municipal officials. The DPA found legal basis under Article 6(1)(c) and (e) GDPR through Spanish local government laws granting councilors access to information necessary for their security functions, but emphasized the principle of data minimization requiring only strictly necessary data.

a7_defendant_name: URBIDE Arabako Ur Patzuergoa-Álava Water Consortium
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found that the Consortium has a legal basis under Article 6(1)(e) GDPR as it exercises public powers and fulfills a mission carried out in the public interest for water supply service management.
a75_case_summary: The Basque DPA issued an opinion on the legality of data transfer from AMVISA to URBIDE Arabako Ur Patzuergoa-Álava Water Consortium for water supply service management. The DPA found the Consortium has legal basis under Article 6(1)(e) GDPR as it exercises public powers and fulfills a mission in the public interest. The opinion outlines GDPR principles that must be complied with but does not find any violations as this is a pre-implementation consultation.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent and public task as legal bases. The DPA found consent invalid due to lack of explicit information and public task invalid due to absence of specific legal authorization under Article 6(3) GDPR.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 03/2020 on the processing of data concerning health for the purpose of scientific research in the context of the COVID-19 outbreak
a75_case_summary: Slovenian authorities established a COVID-19 vaccination interest portal without proper legal basis or transparency. The Information Commissioner found violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 5(1)(b), 5(2), and 13 GDPR due to unclear purposes, inadequate information provision, and lack of lawful basis determination. Joint controllers failed to demonstrate compliance.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed freedom of expression justification under Article 85 GDPR/domestic media law, but the DPA found this disproportionate for birth data, EMŠO numbers, addresses, and data of non-public figures, while accepting it for names of public figures involved in the criminal complaint.
a75_case_summary: A media publisher published a criminal complaint containing unprotected personal data including birth dates, EMŠO numbers, and addresses, with inadequate redaction that allowed data extraction. The DPA found violations of data minimization and security principles under GDPR Article 32, ordering removal of excessive personal data within 5 days while permitting publication of names of public figures based on freedom of expression.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed nature/gravity as aggravating due to inadequate technical measures and sensitive data categories involved, but did not systematically address other Article 83(2) factors.

a75_case_summary: The Information Commissioner issued a non-binding opinion regarding contractual processing of children's data in kindergarten skating activities. The opinion clarifies legal basis requirements under Article 6 GDPR but cannot determine specific legal bases or controller/processor roles without inspection. It emphasizes security obligations under Article 32 GDPR and national law for protecting personal data during physical transmission.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The opinion discusses that banks may process data based on legal obligations, contract, or consent. It notes that requiring detailed personal information solely for account opening could constitute excessive data collection, but cannot determine the specific legal basis without inspection.
a75_case_summary: The Slovenian Information Commissioner provided a non-binding opinion on whether a bank violated GDPR by requesting extensive personal information for account opening. The opinion states that requiring detailed personal data solely for account opening could constitute excessive collection, but a specific determination would require an inspection procedure. The Commissioner advised the complainant to contact the bank for information about the legal basis and purposes of processing.

The Information Commissioner provided a non-binding opinion regarding marketing emails sent to corporate email addresses. The Commissioner determined that corporate email addresses (info@company.si) are not personal data protected under GDPR, as they relate to legal entities rather than individuals. The matter was referred to other authorities (AKOS and Market Inspectorate) as it falls under electronic communications and e-commerce regulations rather than data protection rules.

The Slovenian Information Commissioner provided a non-binding opinion on data subject rights regarding police data processing. The opinion clarifies that access rights for police data are governed by national law (ZVOP-1 Articles 30, 31, 36) rather than GDPR, as police fall under law enforcement processing exemptions. The Commissioner explained the right to access personal data and alternative information request procedures under the Police Tasks and Powers Act.

a7_defendant_name: Government of the Republic of Slovenia
a36_legal_basis_summary: The opinion discusses concerns about whether data can be properly anonymized and emphasizes that if processing involves personal data, an adequate legal basis is required under constitutional provisions and GDPR principles.
a75_case_summary: The Slovenian Information Commissioner provided a non-binding opinion on a proposed COVID-19 data analysis system using anonymized data from various sources. The Commissioner expressed concerns about whether the data could be properly anonymized, particularly regarding location and communication data, and emphasized that if personal data processing occurs, it requires an adequate legal basis under constitutional and GDPR provisions. The opinion warned against using emergency measures to curtail fundamental rights and recommended proper anonymization techniques.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The opinion discusses that telemedicine monitoring requires adequate legal basis in national regulation and appropriate consent if data is used for purposes beyond regular medical care not covered by Article 9(2)(b)-(j) grounds.
a75_case_summary: The Slovenian Information Commissioner issued an opinion on a proposed COVID-19 remote patient monitoring application. The opinion emphasizes the need for proper legal basis, impact assessment, and coordination at EU level. It recommends following EC guidelines and EDPB unified opinions on COVID-19 applications while maintaining fundamental rights protections.

a7_defendant_name: Ministry of Education, Science and Sport
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on Article 9(2)(b) GDPR and national employment law. The DPA found this basis valid for collecting general risk group declarations but invalid for requiring specific health documentation.
a75_case_summary: The Slovenian Information Commissioner issued an opinion regarding COVID-19 workplace safety measures requiring employees to declare if they belong to risk groups. The Commissioner found employers can collect general risk group declarations under Article 9(2)(b) GDPR but cannot require specific health documentation. Employers lack qualification to interpret medical data and should only request general medical certificates confirming risk group status.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The opinion discusses potential legal bases for processing health data under Article 9(2)(c) vital interests, (h) health care provision, and (j) scientific research purposes, and for contact data under compatible purposes for scientific research under Article 6(4).
a75_case_summary: The Slovenian Information Commissioner issued an opinion on whether NIJZ could use data from infectious disease registers to contact COVID-19 survivors for research/treatment purposes. The opinion found potential legal bases under Article 9(2)(c) vital interests, (h) health care, and (j) scientific research for health data processing, and compatible purposes under Article 6(4) for contact data processing.

The Information Commissioner provided a non-binding opinion on whether council meetings of public institutions must be public when discussing personal data. The opinion states institutions can determine session publicity through their statutes but must provide appropriate legal bases under GDPR Article 6 when processing personal data. The Commissioner emphasized consent in public sector requires prior legal definition unless not related to performing public tasks.

Slovenian Information Commissioner issued non-binding opinion regarding hospital employee access to health data. Opinion clarifies that Article 15 GDPR does not entitle individuals to information about specific persons who processed their data. Hospital employees may be considered patients under certain circumstances, triggering obligations under national Patients' Rights Act.

The Slovenian Information Commissioner provided a non-binding opinion on publishing parent council minutes containing teacher names. The opinion states that minutes represent public information but requires careful assessment of which personal data relates to public function performance under the Access to Public Information Act. The Commissioner emphasized this is not a binding decision and cannot assess specific processing outside formal procedures.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The opinion discusses legal basis requirements under Article 6 and 9 GDPR for linking databases but does not assess the validity of any specific legal basis claimed by the controller.
a75_case_summary: The Slovenian Information Commissioner provided a non-binding opinion on temporary linking of health databases (Infectious Diseases Register and Cancer Registry) for COVID-19 research. The Commissioner determined that direct linking would require prior permission under national law since both databases contain sensitive health data and the connection is not for eHealth services. The opinion suggests alternative data transfer methods through existing legal channels instead of direct database linking.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for employment relationship obligations, but the IP found this processing would require valid consent under Article 6(1)(a) since it doesn't relate to employment rights/obligations. Consent must be voluntary without negative consequences for refusal.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 05/2020 on consent under Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: The Slovenian Information Commissioner issued an opinion on mandatory employee participation in video greeting cards. The Commissioner found this processing doesn't relate to employment rights/obligations and would require valid consent under Article 6(1)(a). Consent must be voluntary without negative consequences for refusal, referencing EDPB guidelines on workplace consent.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent but IP found Article 6(1)(c) legal obligation appropriate basis for distance education as public task; consent invalid due to lack of freely given choice
a75_case_summary: Slovenian Information Commissioner provided non-binding opinion on distance education processing; found consent invalid legal basis for student video submissions; recommended Article 6(1)(c) legal obligation as appropriate basis; emphasized data minimization and security requirements under Articles 5 and 32

The Information Commissioner provided a non-binding opinion on drone use by municipalities, clarifying that their competence is limited to monitoring whether drone operators fulfill obligations regarding impact assessments and lawfulness of personal data collection under GDPR, while flight safety and other drone provisions are supervised by the Civil Aviation Agency.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The opinion discusses legal bases generally but does not assess specific legal bases for any particular processing. It emphasizes that employers must have statutory basis or necessity for employment rights/obligations to process employee data.
a75_case_summary: This is an advisory opinion from Slovenia's Information Commissioner regarding employer processing of employee data. The opinion clarifies that employers must have statutory basis or necessity for employment rights/obligations to process employee data, emphasizing the principle of minimum data. It addresses specific questions about labeling equipment with custodian names and locker inspections, stating these require proper legal basis and must be necessary and proportionate.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legal basis under national Insurance Act (ZZavar-1). The DPA found that insurance companies have a legal basis for obtaining and processing personal data to the extent and for purposes stipulated by ZZavar-1, but emphasized the principle of data minimization.
a75_case_summary: The Information Commissioner provided a non-binding opinion on life insurance data processing. The opinion clarifies that insurance companies have a legal basis under national Insurance Act (ZZavar-1) for processing personal data for insurance purposes. The Commissioner emphasized data minimization principles but could not assess specific case compliance without formal proceedings.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller could use Article 6(1)(e) public task or (f) legitimate interest as legal basis due to Triglav National Park Act provisions. The opinion recommends considering these bases if personal data processing cannot be avoided through anonymization.
a75_case_summary: The Information Commissioner provided a non-binding opinion on video surveillance for monitoring recreational activities in Triglav National Park. The opinion recommends anonymized data processing if possible, and if personal data processing is necessary, suggests Article 6(1)(e) public task or (f) legitimate interest as potential legal bases. The Commissioner emphasized the obligation to conduct a Data Protection Impact Assessment before implementing video surveillance in public areas.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The opinion discusses consent as a valid legal basis under Article 6(1)(a) when given electronically, provided it meets conditions of Articles 7 and 8 GDPR, including being voluntary, explicit, informed, unambiguous, and with proper verification for children under 16.
a75_case_summary: The Slovenian Information Commissioner issued an opinion on the validity of electronic consent for accessing digital classrooms during the state of emergency. The opinion clarifies that consent under GDPR Article 6(1)(a) can be given electronically and doesn't require handwritten signatures, but must meet conditions of Articles 7 and 8 including proper information and verification for children under 16. The opinion provides guidance on valid consent mechanisms for educational institutions during the pandemic.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The opinion discusses potential legal bases for processing health data during COVID-19 pandemic, including vital interests of employees, legitimate interests of companies, and public interest. It states consent is not foreseen as legal basis derives from labor law rules, but proportionality must be respected.
a75_case_summary: This is an advisory opinion from Slovenia's Information Commissioner addressing whether employers can require employees to report COVID-19 infections. The opinion states such obligation depends on work nature and must be determined by occupational health professionals. Health data processing may be justified under Article 9 exceptions during pandemic emergency for vital interests protection, but proportionality and data minimization must be respected.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found that employers have a legal basis under Article 6(1)(c) for processing sick leave data through the Employment Relationships Act, which allows processing necessary for exercising rights and obligations arising from employment relationships.
a75_case_summary: This is an advisory opinion on sick leave monitoring by employers. The Slovenian Information Commissioner clarified that employers have a legal basis under Article 6(1)(c) through the Employment Relationships Act to process employee movement regimen and estimated absence time, but cannot obtain medical diagnoses. Employers may hire detectives for this purpose under specific conditions.

The Information Commissioner provided a non-binding opinion on CCTV footage access rights following a car accident complaint. The opinion clarifies that data subjects have right to access footage under Article 15 GDPR but controllers must obscure other individuals' data. Third parties like insurers require proper legal basis under Article 6, with contract performance or legitimate interests as potential grounds.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The Commissioner discussed legal bases under Article 6 GDPR and Article 48 of Slovenian Labor Relations Act, emphasizing that employers can process employee personal data only when necessary for exercising rights/obligations from employment relationship, and must adhere to data minimization principle.
a75_case_summary: The Slovenian Information Commissioner issued a non-binding opinion on employer monitoring of remote workers via tracking applications. The Commissioner emphasized that employers must have legal basis under GDPR Article 6 and Slovenian labor law, adhere to data minimization principles, and provide transparent information under Articles 13-14. Automated collection of screenshots or website visit data was deemed disproportionate interference without legal basis.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The opinion discusses legal bases under Article 6(1) for private sector processing, mentioning consent (a), contract (b), legal obligation/public task (c/e), and legitimate interests (f), but does not make a specific determination about any particular legal basis being valid or invalid for this case.
a75_case_summary: This is an opinion from Slovenia's Information Commissioner regarding a complaint about a photo taken without consent and published in an article. The opinion explains that photographs constitute personal data under GDPR when they identify individuals, and recommends obtaining consent under Article 6(1)(a) for such processing. The Commissioner provides general guidance on legal bases and explains the complaint submission process rather than making a specific determination about violations.

a7_defendant_name: Ministry of Education, Science and Sport
a36_legal_basis_summary: The Commissioner found consent invalid for teacher recordings and distance education, recommending legal obligation (Art 6(1)(c)) for children's data and public task basis for educational institutions.
a75_case_summary: Opinion addresses teacher's concerns about distance education data processing. Commissioner finds consent invalid basis for teacher recordings and student data processing, recommends legal obligation basis under Article 6(1)(c) and emphasizes data minimization principles. Security concerns raised regarding third-country data transfers and use of communication tools.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legal basis under national Insurance Act Article 268; DPA found this provides lawful basis for processing health data; Key reasoning was that insurance companies are entitled to obtain relevant medical records necessary for deciding insurance claims
a75_case_summary: Slovenian Information Commissioner issued non-binding opinion on insurance company's request for 5-year-old medical records; Found insurance companies entitled to relevant medical records under national Insurance Act Article 268; Advised data subject on transparency obligations under Article 13; Did not assess necessity of 5-year timeframe as this was advisory opinion

a36_legal_basis_summary: The opinion discusses that processing of researchers' data for research title appointments may be permissible under Article 6(1)(e) as a public task, and notes that employment data of public servants may constitute freely available public information rather than protected personal data.
a75_case_summary: The Slovenian Information Commissioner provided a non-binding opinion on whether research title appointment data constitutes personal data inaccessible to a Scientific Council. The opinion states that processing researchers' data for title appointments may be permissible under Article 6(1)(e) as a public task, and employment data of public servants may constitute freely available public information rather than protected personal data. The final assessment must be made by the controller based on internal regulations.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The opinion discusses legal bases under Article 6 but does not assess any specific legal basis for the municipality's processing; it states the municipality must identify an appropriate legal basis if one exists for disclosing objectors' signatures and identities.
a75_case_summary: The Slovenian Information Commissioner provided a non-binding opinion on whether handwritten signatures of objectors to municipal land sale constitute personal data. The opinion confirms signatures are personal data when they identify individuals. The Commissioner declined to assess whether the municipality had a legal basis for disclosure, stating this requires inspection procedures with full documentation.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legal basis under Article 6(1)(b) contract and Article 6(1)(f) legitimate interests for quarantine supervision. The DPA found both bases invalid as quarantine supervision is not necessary for employment relationship rights/obligations and is an administrative measure reserved for state authorities.
a75_case_summary: Slovenian Information Commissioner issued opinion on employer quarantine supervision. Found systematic monitoring of employee quarantine implementation (home visits, mobile apps) impermissible under GDPR. Only permissible for employer to receive proof of quarantine order and related information necessary for employment rights/obligations. Quarantine supervision is administrative measure reserved for state authorities, not necessary for employment relationship.

a2_authority_name: Information Commissioner of the Republic of Slovenia
a36_legal_basis_summary: The opinion discusses consent under Article 6(1)(a) as potentially valid for travel data collection if not coerced, and mentions Article 48 of ZDR-1 and other laws as possible bases for health data processing in employment context.
a75_case_summary: This is an advisory opinion from Slovenia's Information Commissioner addressing COVID-19 workplace measures. The opinion states employers must take a holistic approach to infection prevention, assessing necessity and proportionality of any personal data processing. For health testing, employers must follow competent authorities' instructions and may collect only necessary information. For travel data, such processing generally infringes privacy unless based on valid non-coerced consent.
authority_name_raw: Information Commissioner of the Republic of Slovenia
authority_name_norm: Information Commissioner of the Republic of Slovenia

a36_legal_basis_summary: The opinion finds no appropriate legal basis for systematic collection of holiday location data under GDPR, ZVOP-1 or Employment Relationships Act. Consent would likely not be valid in employment context. Specific COVID-19 measures may be conditionally permitted under national regulations.
a75_case_summary: Slovenian Information Commissioner issued non-binding opinion on employer COVID-19 measures. Found no legal basis for systematic collection of holiday location data under GDPR or national laws. Conditionally permitted temperature measurement and COVID-19 test certification under specific national regulations. Consent deemed unlikely valid in employment context.

a7_defendant_name: Ministry of Education, Science and Sport
a36_legal_basis_summary: The opinion discusses legal bases under Article 6(1)(c) and 6(1)(e) for public sector processing, finding no explicit legal basis exists for collecting mask refusal data in applicable education laws or epidemiological regulations.
a75_case_summary: The Slovenian Information Commissioner issued an opinion regarding schools collecting lists of students refusing to wear protective masks. The Commissioner found no explicit legal basis for such processing in education laws or epidemiological regulations. An inspection procedure was initiated to verify the legality of this data collection practice. The opinion emphasized that consent cannot be valid if obtained through coercion or as a condition.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller proposed using Article 9 or 10 of ZVOP-1 as legal basis, but the DPA determined that electronic communications operators must use legal bases from ZEKom-1 (Slovenian Electronic Communications Act) rather than GDPR Article 6 bases, and found no direct legal basis in ZEKom-1 for voluntary SMS notifications initiated by NIJZ.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Opinion 5/2019 on the interplay between the ePrivacy Directive and the GDPR
a75_case_summary: The Slovenian Information Commissioner issued an opinion on the legality of sending SMS notifications about the #StayHealthy app. The Commissioner determined that electronic communications operators must use legal bases from the Electronic Communications Act (ZEKom-1) rather than GDPR Article 6 bases, and found no direct legal basis in ZEKom-1 for voluntary SMS notifications initiated by NIJZ. The opinion referenced EDPB Opinion 5/2019 on the relationship between GDPR and ePrivacy rules.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The authority states that processing health data (temperature measurement) is generally prohibited unless exceptions apply, and recommends consulting medical professionals to determine necessity and justification before introducing such measures.
a75_case_summary: Slovenian DPA provides non-binding opinion on workplace temperature monitoring and time recording using cameras. States health data processing generally prohibited unless exceptions apply. Recommends consulting medical professionals before implementation. Notes biometric time recording generally not allowed as invasive when milder alternatives exist.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing under Article 6(1)(c) based on legal obligations under ZPPDFT-1. The DPA found this legal basis valid for obtaining legally required information from politically exposed persons and their immediate family members, provided appropriate procedures are established.
a75_case_summary: The Slovenian Information Commissioner issued a non-binding opinion regarding a bank's request for asset information from a politically exposed person. The Commissioner found that Article 6(1)(c) GDPR provides a valid legal basis for processing when banks comply with anti-money laundering legislation requirements. The Commissioner noted it lacks competence to assess the adequacy of the bank's risk assessment procedures, referring this to other competent authorities.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on legal obligation under Insurance Act Article 268. The DPA found Article 6(1)(c) and Article 9(2)(h) could provide valid legal bases if conditions are met. The DPA emphasized the need for data minimization and purpose limitation.
a75_case_summary: Opinion request regarding transmission of medical reports to insurance company based on cooperation agreement. DPA clarified that processing requires legal basis under Article 6(1) and Article 9(2) of GDPR. Insurance Act Article 268 provides potential legal basis but must comply with data minimization principle.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The opinion discusses that both the forum and Facebook would need appropriate legal bases as joint controllers for data processing related to advertising, mentioning consent, contract, law, vital interests, public task, and legitimate interests as possible bases under Article 6.
a75_case_summary: The Slovenian Information Commissioner issued a non-binding opinion regarding Facebook ads containing forum posts. The opinion clarifies that if the individual is identifiable, this constitutes personal data processing requiring appropriate legal basis under Article 6 GDPR. The Commissioner noted this might be a joint controller situation between the forum and Facebook, but couldn't make concrete assessments as it was an opinion rather than an inspection procedure.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The authority found that Article 9(2)(e) provides a legal basis for processing special category data when the data subject has made the data public themselves, permitting further disclosure of health information obtained from a publicly accessible blog.
