Security measures were inadequate as employee passwords were stored with obsolete MD4 algorithm.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating; actions to mitigate damage and cooperation as mitigating; technical measures as aggravating; categories of data affected as aggravating; other factors as mitigating. Fine was reduced from proposed amount due to mitigating factors.
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Information Technology and Freedoms
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Information Technology and Freedoms

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties
a7_defendant_name: Ministry of Transformation and Public Service
a36_legal_basis_summary: The ministries claimed public interest mission of information, but CNIL found the processing constituted political communication incompatible with the authorized purposes under Decree No. 2022-1446 governing ENSAP processing.
a75_case_summary: French ministries used ENSAP database of 2.3M public officials to send political communication about pension reform. CNIL found this violated purpose limitation under Article 5(1)(b) as the processing was incompatible with ENSAP's authorized administrative purposes. The restricted formation issued a call to order against both ministries as joint controllers.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: CNIL considered the large number of affected persons (2.3M) as aggravating and the ministries' remedial actions (census of opt-outs and planned interface improvements) as mitigating. Other Article 83(2) factors were not discussed.
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Information Technology and Freedoms
a75_case_summary: The municipality of Kourou failed to appoint a data protection officer despite being required to do so since May 25,2018 and ignored multiple CNIL communications including a formal notice and previous fine. The CNIL imposed a €5,000 fine for breaches of Articles 31 and 37 GDPR and issued an injunction with daily penalty for non-compliance.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including nature/gravity/duration (aggravating), intentional/negligent character (aggravating), previous infringements (aggravating), cooperation with authority (aggravating), and compliance with prior orders (aggravating). The financial situation of the municipality was considered in determining the fine amount.
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Information Technology and Freedoms
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Information Technology and Freedoms

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) for employee monitoring. The DPA found this legal basis invalid as the processing was disproportionate and excessively infringed on employees' rights to privacy and working conditions that respect health and safety.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on transparency under Regulation 2016/679;Opinion 06/2014 on the notion of legitimate interests
a75_case_summary: Amazon France Logistique implemented excessive employee monitoring through scanner data collection, processing detailed productivity/quality indicators and inactivity periods. The CNIL found violations of data minimization, legal basis, transparency and security obligations. The processing created disproportionate pressure on workers through constant surveillance of their actions to the nearest second.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, intentional/negligent character as aggravating, actions to mitigate damage as mitigating, and cooperation with authority as mitigating. The fine was set at €32 million considering the seriousness and company turnover.
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Information Technology and Freedoms
a75_case_summary: The CNIL sanctioned Yahoo EMEA Limited for violating Article 82 of the French Data Protection Act regarding cookies. The company deposited advertising cookies without prior consent and obstructed consent withdrawal by threatening loss of service access. The fine was based on breach severity, duration, and number of affected users (approximately 5 million).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, categories of personal data as aggravating, and cooperation as neutral. Other factors were not discussed.
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Information Technology and Freedoms
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Information Technology and Freedoms

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis for data transmission to partners for commercial prospecting. The DPA found consent invalid due to forms that did not allow unequivocal, free, informed consent through clear positive action.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 5/2020 on consent;Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of the amount of administrative fines
a75_case_summary: The CNIL sanctioned TAGADAMEDIA for invalid consent collection methods on competition/survey websites that transmitted prospect data to partners for commercial prospecting. The DPA found forms did not allow free, specific, informed consent through clear positive action. The company also breached Article 30 by maintaining an incomplete processing register that didn't distinguish controllers between TAGADAMEDIA and its subsidiary.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating and cooperation/mitigation actions as mitigating. The fine was reduced from the proposed €500,000 to €75,000 based on company's financial capacity and cooperation.
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties
a7_defendant_name: Ministry of the Interior and Overseas
a75_case_summary: CNIL opinion on draft decree implementing algorithmic processing on images from video protection systems and aircraft cameras for 2024 Olympics. The opinion addresses design phase, operation phase, and improvement phase of algorithmic processing to detect predetermined security events. CNIL recommends limiting information exemptions and completing impact assessments before operational deployment.
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties
a36_legal_basis_summary: The processing is lawful under Article 6(1)(e) GDPR as necessary for execution of public interest mission. Health data processing meets condition under Article 9(2)(j) GDPR for scientific research purposes.
a75_case_summary: CNIL authorizes Brain and Spinal Cord Institute to process health data for epilepsy epidemiology study. Processing lawful under Article 6(1)(e) and Article 9(2)(j) GDPR for scientific research. Authorization includes specific security measures and data retention limit of 5 years.
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties
a7_defendant_name: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties
a36_legal_basis_summary: The CNIL establishes that processing under this methodology must be based on Article 6(1)(e) (public task) as controllers must act within their public interest mission or exercise of public authority.
a75_case_summary: The CNIL approves reference methodology MR-007 for processing SNDS health data by public interest organizations for research/study/evaluation purposes. The methodology establishes security requirements, transparency measures, and compliance procedures for controllers using pseudonymized health data from France's National Health Data System. It specifies that processing must be based on public interest missions and requires CESREES approval before implementation.
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Information Technology and Freedoms
a7_defendant_name: DE PARTICULIER A PARTICULIER – EDITIONS NERESSIS
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legal obligations under Consumer Code justified retention periods;DPA found retention excessive for contracts under €120 and for user data beyond defined periods;Key reasoning was that Consumer Code obligations only apply to contracts ≥€120 and retention periods must be strictly applied
a75_case_summary: CNIL found DE PARTICULIER A PARTICULIER – EDITIONS NERESSIS violated GDPR articles 5-1-e)(storage limitation),13(transparency),28(subprocessing),and 32(security);Violations included excessive data retention,incomplete privacy policy,inadequate subcontractor contracts,and insufficient password security measures;The company implemented corrective measures during proceedings but remained liable for past breaches;CNIL imposed €100,000 fine considering nature,gravity,and company cooperation
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically;Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration of violations,intentional/negligent character,and inadequate technical measures;Mitigating factors included actions to mitigate damage,cooperation with authority,and other mitigating circumstances;No factors were discussed as neutral
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Information Technology and Freedoms
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Information Technology and Freedoms

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Information Technology and Freedoms
a36_legal_basis_summary: Company claimed legitimate interest and consent for telemarketing;DPA found both invalid;Consent forms did not allow clear/unambiguous positive act and legitimate interest assessment was insufficient
a75_case_summary: FORIOU conducted telemarketing using prospect files purchased from data brokers;DPA found both legitimate interest and consent legal bases invalid;Consent forms from data brokers did not allow clear/unambiguous positive acts;Fine of €310,000 imposed for Article 6 violation
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating factor;Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed;No mention of intentionality, mitigation efforts, or cooperation
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Information Technology and Freedoms
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Information Technology and Freedoms

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Information Technology and Freedoms
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest and consent as legal bases for telephone prospecting. The DPA found both invalid - consent was not freely given through competition forms, and legitimate interest was invalid as data subjects couldn't reasonably expect prospecting from HUBSIDE.STORE.
a75_case_summary: HUBSIDE.STORE conducted mass marketing via SMS and phone calls using prospect files purchased from data brokers. The CNIL found invalid consent collection through competition forms that didn't allow clear choice, and invalid legitimate interest as data subjects couldn't reasonably expect prospecting. The company also failed to provide adequate information to data subjects under Article 14. A €525,000 fine was imposed for breaches of CPCE Article L.34-5 and GDPR Articles 6 and 14.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature and gravity of violations as aggravating factors, particularly the fundamental nature of the principles breached and the massive scale of processing. The company's financial capacity and market position were also considered in determining the fine amount.
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Information Technology and Freedoms
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Information Technology and Freedoms

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Informatics and Liberties
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed data was anonymous and thus not subject to GDPR; the DPA found the data was pseudonymized health data requiring compliance with GDPR and French health data authorization requirements.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of controller and processor in the GDPR;Opinion 05/2014 on anonymization techniques
a75_case_summary: CEGEDIM SANTÉ collected pseudonymized health data from doctors' patient records via its CROSSWAY software to create a health data warehouse for commercial studies. The CNIL found the data was not anonymous but pseudonymized, requiring authorization under French health data laws. The company breached Article 66 of French Data Protection Law and Article 5(1)(a) GDPR by unlawfully collecting HRi teleservice data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including nature/gravity/duration (aggravating), categories of personal data (aggravating), and cooperation with authority (mitigating). The fine was set at €800,000 considering the severity, scope of processing, and sensitive health data involved.
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Informatics and Liberties
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Informatics and Liberties

a75_case_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Commission nationale de l'informatique et des libertés
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f); DPA found this invalid as processing went against data subjects' reasonable expectations when they restricted visibility of contact details; No valid legal basis established for processing.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on transparency under Regulation (EU) 2016/679;Guidelines on the rights of data subjects - right of access
a75_case_summary: KASPR developed a browser extension that collected professional contact details from LinkedIn users, including those who restricted visibility. CNIL found breaches of Articles 5(1)(e),6,12,14,15 GDPR. Processing lacked legal basis as legitimate interest invalid when against data subjects' reasonable expectations. Company ordered to cease unlawful collection and improve transparency.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to fundamental principle violations affecting millions. Intentional/negligent character was aggravating as company showed negligence. Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating as company implemented some compliance measures. Other aggravating factors included financial benefits derived from unlawful processing.
authority_name_raw: Commission nationale de l'informatique et des libertés
authority_name_norm: Commission nationale de l'informatique et des libertés

a75_case_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Information Technology and Civil Liberties
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest for data transmission; DPA found consent required for electronic prospecting; Legal basis discussion focused on validity of consent collection methods.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 5/2020 on consent within the meaning of Regulation (EU) 2016/679
a75_case_summary: CALOGA processed prospect data for electronic marketing without valid consent; DPA found breaches of storage limitation, lawful basis, and French e-privacy rules; Company failed to verify consent validity from partners and implemented problematic withdrawal mechanisms.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Art 83(2) factors discussed; Nature/gravity/duration and intentional/negligent character were aggravating; Financial advantage from violations was aggravating; Company's ceased trading was considered.
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Information Technology and Civil Liberties
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Information Technology and Civil Liberties

a75_case_summary: CNIL sanctioned a controller and processor for failing to implement adequate security measures against credential stuffing attacks on an e-commerce website. Between 2018-2020, attackers accessed personal data of approximately 40,000 customers including names, email addresses, loyalty card information, and order details. The companies were slow to develop effective countermeasures, taking a year to implement a bot detection tool while simpler measures like IP rate limiting or CAPTCHA could have been deployed faster.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The CNIL considered the nature/gravity/duration of infringement as aggravating due to prolonged vulnerability period. The intentional/negligent character was aggravating due to delayed response. Technical/organizational measures were aggravating as security measures were insufficient. Categories of data affected were aggravating as sensitive customer data was compromised. Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating as companies eventually implemented security improvements.
authority_name_norm: Commission Nationale de l'Informatique et des Libertés

a75_case_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

Controller experienced security breach due to excessive staff access to website forms database; modified forms to prevent storage; issued Article 34 notifications but public notice contained misleading statement about personal notifications; DPA found breach of transparency obligations under Articles 5(1)(a) and 12(1) because approximately 7000 data subjects could not be personally notified but notice suggested they had been.

Healthcare provider's online appointment system allowed booking using only name and social security number without proper identification. DPA found this violated Article 32 security requirements as it enabled ghost appointments and identity theft risks. The system processed special category health data without adequate security measures. DPA issued compliance order requiring reliable identification methods.
NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on legal requirements under Credit Information Act, but DPA found the method of assessing judgments case-by-case led to processing without proper legal basis under GDPR Article 6.
a75_case_summary: The Finnish DPA found Suomen Asiakastieto Oy violated GDPR by failing to comply with an order to remove incorrect payment default entries from credit registers. The controller's case-by-case assessment of court judgments led to processing without proper legal basis. The sanction board imposed a €440,000 fine for non-compliance with the supervisory authority's order, considering the intentional nature and financial benefit of avoiding compliance costs.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity of breach, intentional character, responsibility level, and financial benefit from avoiding compliance costs. Mitigating factor was actions taken to mitigate damage. Neutral factors included previous infringements, cooperation level, and manner infringement became known.

a75_case_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful under Finnish Credit Information Act provisions for default entries based on final judgments. The DPA found no valid legal basis under GDPR Article 6 when judgments resulted from disputed cases where payment obligation was reasonably contested.
a75_case_summary: The Finnish DPA ordered a credit registry to correct erroneous default entries based on final court judgments. The DPA found that judgments resulting from disputed cases where payment obligation was reasonably contested cannot indicate insolvency or unwillingness to pay. The controller's case-by-case assessment approach violated GDPR lawfulness principles and Finnish credit information requirements.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature/gravity/duration of infringement aggravating due to large-scale processing and significant impact on data subjects' rights. Technical/organizational measures were aggravating as the controller failed to implement proper safeguards. Categories of personal data affected were aggravating due to sensitive financial information. Other mitigating factors included difficult legal interpretation of Credit Information Act conditions.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller invoked legitimate interests for public safety; DPA found information outdated and no longer justified; ordered removal under right to erasure
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 5/2019 on the criteria of the Right to be Forgotten in the search engines cases under the GDPR;guidelines on the implementation of the Court of Justice of the European Union judgment on Google Spain and Inc v. Agencia Española de Protección de Datos (AEPD) and Mario Costeja González C-131/12
a75_case_summary: Applicant requested removal of search results linking to outdated wanted notice; Google invoked legitimate interests for public safety; DPA found information no longer socially relevant as warrant expired in 2011; ordered removal under Article 17 right to erasure

a36_legal_basis_summary: The legal basis was not assessed; the decision focused solely on data minimization principles regardless of processing basis
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 4/2019 on built-in and default data protection pursuant to Article 25
a75_case_summary: A Finnish municipality collected bank account numbers from all students for scholarship payments, though only some students receive scholarships. The Deputy Data Protection Commissioner found this violated Article 5(1)(c) data minimization principle as collecting data from all students "just to be sure" was unnecessary. The controller was issued a reprimand and ordered to bring processing into compliance and delete unnecessarily collected account numbers.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent but DPA found consent invalid as it was not individualized and informed; consent did not specify types of data collected and purposes of processing; health data processing requires explicit consent which was not obtained.
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA fined company €122,000 for processing health data without valid consent; consent was not individualized and informed as required; health data processing was core business activity; case handled through OSS mechanism with other EU authorities.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered health data nature as aggravating; processing scale as core business activity was aggravating; no other Art 83(2) factors discussed systematically.
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner

a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on data subject rights - Right of access;Guidelines 3/2019 on the processing of personal data by video equipment
a75_case_summary: The Police University of Applied Sciences refused to provide video recordings of a screening test to a data subject, citing Article 15(4) GDPR protection of others' rights. The DPA found the controller failed to demonstrate specific harm to others' rights and ordered provision of the recordings. The DPA emphasized that Article 15(4) requires case-specific assessment, not general claims of potential harm.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA investigated municipal registrar's failure to have data processing agreement with website management company that processed student data through contact forms. The registrar lacked contractual documentation required under Article 28(3) GDPR but had since ceased using the processor. The DPA issued a reprimand but no fine due to the defendant's public administration status.
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner

a75_case_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a75_case_summary: Forenom Oy experienced a data security breach in March 2020 where an attacker gained access to approximately 165,000 personal data records through SQL injection vulnerability. The DPA found violations of data minimization, storage limitation, and security obligations. The controller was ordered to reassess data retention periods and received a reprimand for security deficiencies.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, actions to mitigate damage as mitigating, technical measures as aggravating, cooperation as mitigating, and categories of data as aggravating. No fine was imposed despite these findings.
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Officer
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA found parking company X Oy violated data minimization principle when technical failures in parking machines forced customers to provide phone numbers for SMS receipts instead of offering paper receipts; The DPA determined phone numbers were not necessary for receipt provision and the company failed to implement adequate technical measures; The controller was ordered to bring processing into compliance with GDPR principles; The case originated from a data subject complaint about mandatory phone number collection for receipts.
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Officer
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Officer

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Officer
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed no processing criterion was defined; DPA found no legal basis assessed under Articles 6 and 9; Processing would require both Article 6 basis and Article 9 exception for health data
a75_case_summary: Housing association required residents to report COVID-19 infections to property manager for cleaning efficiency; DPA found no legal basis assessed under Articles 6 and 9 for processing health data; Violated data minimization principle and built-in data protection requirements; Warning issued as no actual data collected
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Officer
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Officer

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a74_guidelines_referenced: WP29 Guidelines on the Reporting of a Personal Data Breach under Regulation (EU) 2016/679;Report of the Working Party on the Implementation of the EU General Data Protection Regulation (TATTI)
a75_case_summary: The Finnish DPA found the Ministry of Foreign Affairs violated Articles 33 and 34 GDPR by failing to report a Pegasus spyware security breach within 72 hours and not notifying data subjects without undue delay. The breach targeted posted personnel abroad. The controller cited national security and investigation complexities as reasons for delay, but the DPA found these insufficient justification under GDPR requirements. A reprimand was issued instead of a fine considering the circumstances.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature and gravity of the breach (Article 83(2)(a)) as aggravating factors, noting the breach targeted posted personnel working abroad. The categories of personal data affected (Article 83(2)(g)) were also considered aggravating. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed there was a GDPR agreement dated 24 May 2018, but the DPA found it did not fulfill the requirements of Article 28(3) GDPR. The DPA determined no proper data processing agreement existed between the parties.
a75_case_summary: Y Oy processed personal data as a processor for XX Oy in telemarketing operations without a proper data processing agreement as required by Article 28(3) GDPR. The DPA found Y Oy neglected its obligation to draw up such an agreement. While the breach was considered serious, no fine was imposed due to Y Oy's ceased operations, low turnover, and pending bankruptcy proceedings.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature of Y Oy's business and knowing failure to comply as aggravating factors. Mitigating factors included Y Oy's ceased operations, low turnover (€839.33), and pending bankruptcy application. The sanction panel ultimately found imposing a fine would be disproportionate.
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2019 on Article 25 Data Protection by Design and by Default
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA found a parking management company violated data minimization principles by displaying property addresses on parking permits. The controller argued address information was necessary for parking enforcement, but the DPA determined numeric identifiers could achieve the same purpose without revealing addresses. The DPA issued a reprimand and ordered the controller to bring processing into compliance by removing address information from parking permits.
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA ordered electricity supplier to comply with data subject's access request regarding recorded sales call and personal information. Controller failed to provide call recordings and adequate information about data sources. DPA found violations of transparency obligations and right of access under GDPR Articles 5(1)(a), 12, and 15.
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman
a75_case_summary: Applicant sought access to full OP bonus account information including wife's bonus data. DPA found no right of access exists due to bank secrecy protecting wife's financial status. Disclosure would adversely affect wife's rights under Article 15(4) GDPR.
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent but DPA found consent invalid due to lack of voluntariness and informed choice; controller later stated legal obligation but did not specify which; DPA found legal basis not transparently informed
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA issued reprimand to municipal early childhood education provider for failing to transparently inform parents about purpose and legal basis of processing personal data collected via COVID-19 questionnaire; Controller initially claimed consent but DPA found consent invalid due to lack of voluntariness and clarity; Purpose remained unclear whether for childcare arrangements, payment refunds, or both
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing based on Article 6(1)(b) for contract implementation and national law Section 6(1)(1) of Data Protection Act. DPA found national provision only applies to insured persons, not applicants, and processing violated Article 9.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 05/2020 on consent according to the General Data Protection Regulation
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA investigated insurance company's practice of requesting extensive health data from healthcare units during insurance application phase. DPA found processing of health data violated Article 9 GDPR as national exemption only applied to insured persons, not applicants. DPA ordered controller to bring processing into compliance and implement proper data minimization measures.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed public task as legal basis for participatory budgeting service. The DPA did not explicitly invalidate this legal basis but found violations of Articles 25 and 32 regarding data protection by design and security measures.
a75_case_summary: A municipal participatory budgeting service made user profiles publicly searchable and visible, exposing approximately 160,000 individuals' names and activity data. The DPA found violations of Articles 25(2) (data protection by design and by default) and 32(1) (security of processing) as profiles were unnecessarily accessible to unlimited persons. The controller received a reprimand but no fine, as corrective measures had already been implemented.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature of the infringement as aggravating (profiles publicly accessible without limitation) and the controller's remedial actions as mitigating (deleted profiles, removed search function). Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner

a75_case_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

The EDPS considered whether a private trader has right of access to call recordings under Article 15 GDPR. The authority found that voice recordings constitute personal data and the applicant had right of access. The controller complied by providing information in writing format, which was deemed appropriate under Articles 12(1) and 15(3).
NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests for processing purchase data throughout customer relationship; DPA found this violated storage limitation principle as retention period was not purpose-specific and could extend for decades.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 4/2019 on built-in and default data protection pursuant to Article 25 Version 2.0;EDPB Guidelines 02/2021 on virtual assistants controlled by voice commands Version 2.0
a75_case_summary: Kesko Oyj processed customer purchase data through its Plussa loyalty program, storing detailed purchase information throughout the customer relationship without purpose-specific retention periods. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(c), 5(1)(e), 25(1) and 25(2) GDPR regarding data minimization, storage limitation, and data protection by design/default. The controller was ordered to define purpose-specific retention periods and delete/anonymize data exceeding these periods.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors but did not impose a fine. Factors considered aggravating included nature/gravity/duration of infringement, technical/organizational measures, and categories of data affected. The sanctions panel found mitigating factors in that storage periods had not yet become disproportionately long compared to industry practice.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent and legitimate interest; DPA found consent invalid due to power imbalance; No legal basis established for location data processing
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines for consent according to Regulation 2016/679 05/2020
a75_case_summary: University processed employee location data via mobile app for time stamping; DPA found no legal basis under Article 6 and violation of data minimization principle; Processing ban imposed and €25,000 fine for violations of Articles 5 and 6
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Art 83(2) factors; Aggravating: nature/duration, negligence, data categories, vulnerable position; Mitigating: cooperation, no previous violations, no financial gain; Fine reduced due to non-profit educational mission
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner

a75_case_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing based on patient consent and various regulations; DPA found no valid legal basis identified for processing patient data in step 1; Controller failed to specify which regulation served as legal basis.
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA issued warning regarding planned healthcare profiling system; Controller failed to identify automated individual decisions under Article 22 for patients not selected for closer examination; Controller also lacked legal basis under Articles 6 and 9 for processing patient data in risk model development phase; DPA found processing likely violated GDPR principles.

Healthcare provider failed to adequately protect personal data when CEO's computer bag containing laptop, external hard drives, and paper documents was stolen from car. Data included special category health data of approximately 3,000 patients. DPA found violation of Article 32 security requirements due to lack of encryption and improper handling of physical documents.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity of infringement aggravating due to special category health data involved. Technical/organizational measures were found aggravating due to inadequate security protections. Categories of personal data affected was aggravating due to sensitive health information.

a75_case_summary: Travel agency processed visa applications via unencrypted HTTP protocol, storing personal data including passport numbers on open web server. DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(f), 17(1), 25(1), and 32(1)-(2) GDPR. Company declared bankrupt during proceedings but group structure considered for fine allocation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity/duration, negligence, no mitigation actions, inadequate technical measures, no cooperation, passport data risk. Mitigating: no special category data. Neutral: no previous infringements.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary to comply with legal obligations (Art 6(1)(c)). The DPA found this valid for collecting personal identity numbers under Section 29(2) of the Data Protection Act for fee recovery purposes.
a75_case_summary: The Finnish DPA addressed a complaint about the Supreme Court requiring personal identity numbers for billing document requests. The DPA found it lacked competence over judicial document disclosure functions but had competence over fee collection processing. The Court was found to have legal basis for processing identity numbers under national law for fee recovery purposes, but was asked to reassess risks regarding potential disclosure of requesters' information.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful under Finnish Credit Information Act, but DPA found no valid legal basis under GDPR Article 6 as conditions for default entry were not met.
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA ordered credit registry to correct erroneous default entries based on final court judgments. The DPA found that disputed cases where defendants reasonably contested payment obligations should not result in default entries, as they don't demonstrate insolvency or unwillingness to pay. The controller's case-by-case assessment method violated GDPR lawfulness principle and Finnish credit information requirements.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered large-scale processing and significant impact on data subject rights as aggravating. Incomplete disclosure practices by Legal Register Center were considered mitigating. Imposition of administrative fine was deemed disproportionate due to difficult interpretation of Credit Information Act conditions.
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman

a75_case_summary: A data subject complained about a debt collection agency retaining personal data beyond necessary periods. The agency claimed retention was justified under accounting and debt collection laws. The Assistant Data Protection Officer found that only accounting-related data could be retained beyond 5 years, and ordered deletion of non-accounting data like emails.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on legal obligation under Motor Insurance Act; DPA found the interpretation overly broad and violating minimization principles; Controller must limit data collection to what is strictly necessary for compensation cases
a75_case_summary: Finnish Motor Insurance Center systematically requested full patient visit records instead of targeted statements for compensation cases; DPA found this violated data minimization, reasonableness, and default data protection principles; Controller claimed legal basis under Motor Insurance Act but DPA found interpretation overly broad; Fine imposed due to systematic nature, focus on health data, and long duration of violation
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors; Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration, intentional/negligent character, lack of mitigation actions, inadequate technical measures, and focus on sensitive health data; No mitigating factors identified; Cooperation was neutral as it was statutory obligation

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a7_defendant_name: Helmet libraries in the capital region: Helsinki, Espoo, Vantaa and the city of Kauniainen
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller processed personal data through tracking technologies without a valid legal basis, violating Articles 5(1)(a) and 6(1) GDPR.
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA found Helmet libraries violated GDPR by using tracking technologies without legal basis, inadequately informing data subjects, and transferring data to US without proper safeguards. The libraries installed tracking technologies before obtaining consent and material search data could leak to third parties. The DPA issued orders to destroy unlawfully collected data and bring processing into compliance.
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was permitted under Section 6(1)(1) of the Data Protection Act, but the DPA found this provision only applies to insured persons and claimants, not insurance applicants. The DPA determined consent was invalid due to lack of specificity and voluntariness.
a75_case_summary: The Finnish DPA found an insurance company violated GDPR by processing health data of insurance applicants using overly broad consent forms. The company claimed authority under national insurance law, but the DPA ruled this only applies to insured persons, not applicants. The DPA ordered compliance with Article 9 and found the consent mechanism insufficiently specific and voluntary.

Finnish DPA found controller violated Article 32 security requirements for online appointment booking system that allowed brute-force attacks to determine personal identification numbers. The system processed personal IDs on large scale without adequate security measures. Controller implemented strong identification after breach was discovered.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration and technical measures as aggravating factors. Actions to mitigate damage and other factors were mitigating since controller fixed vulnerability promptly after discovery.

a75_case_summary: Municipality breached GDPR principles by making students' personal data (name, email, school, class) visible in email address book across all schools. DPA found this violated data minimization, lawfulness/fairness, and confidentiality principles as wide visibility was unnecessary for educational purposes. Controller ordered to limit data visibility to necessary groups only.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on Article 6(1)(a) and (c) but the DPA did not evaluate legal bases, focusing instead on principles violations.
a75_case_summary: The Finnish DPA found a municipal education authority violated GDPR principles by making students' personal data (names, roles, email addresses, schools, classes) visible in email address books across all city schools. The controller failed to demonstrate necessity for such wide visibility. The DPA issued a reprimand and compliance order to limit data visibility to necessary contexts.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly, finding the nature/gravity (widespread children's data exposure), inadequate technical measures, and sensitive data categories as aggravating factors for the violation.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Supervisor
a75_case_summary: A patient requested access to X-ray and MRI images from a hospital district, which charged €25 fee citing hospital practice. The DPA found the hospital violated Articles 12(5), 15(1) and 15(3) GDPR by charging for first copies of personal data. The DPA ordered the hospital to comply with the data subject's request and bring processing operations into compliance with GDPR.
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Supervisor
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Supervisor

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent for direct marketing but DPA found consent invalid as it was forced/not voluntary; customers had to consent to marketing to purchase tickets online
a75_case_summary: Finnkino required forced consent for direct marketing as condition for ticket purchases; failed to properly implement right to object; used excessive identification procedures requiring passport photos; failed to inform about call recording; DPA issued reprimand and order to comply due to unclear legal situation and company's spontaneous remedial actions
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered unclear legal situation since GDPR application as mitigating; Finnkino's spontaneous remedial actions were mitigating; reprehensible conduct did not require heavier penalty than reprimand
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman
